summary: we monitored patients admitted with respiratory infections (RI) in 9 Berlin hospitals from 7.12.2009 to 12.12.2010 according to different case definitions. we determined the proportion of cases with influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 (pH1N1)pdm09 (pH1N1). 45% of hospitalized PCR-positive pH1N1-patients did not fulfil the SARI case-definition that included shortness of breath or difficulty breathing. broader, alternative case definitions should be considered to assess influenza-related disease burden in hospitals. a number of countries within the WHO European region have recently established SARI surveillance of different scope and profile. in germany, systems to estimate the burden of severe disease due to influenza were not well established during the 2009 influenza pandemic. in the winter of 2009/10 a hospital-based pandemic influenza vaccine effectiveness study was launched. study period 1 was time with significant influenza circulation which lasted from December 7, 2009 to January 10, 2010, followed by study period 2 with low or absent circulation during the spring, summer, and autumn months of 2010. data collection The hospital information-system (ORBIS) of 9 community hospitals of the Vivantes Network for Health was screened daily for newly admitted patients. a study team comprised of 9 study nurses and additional 12 study assistants was assigned to these locations. CD4 was the narrowest case definition and was identical to the SARI case definition as suggested by ECDC and WHO in 2009. CD2 included only those CD1 patients who fulfilled the specified clinical criteria and excluded those CD1 patients based only on a suspected diagnosis of RI. patients received a nasal and throat swab (Mastaswab; MAST Diagnostica, Reinfeld, Germany) to obtain material for real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing at the Reference Centre for Influenza. the limit of detection (95% detection probability) was determined at 6 genome equivalents per reaction indicating a high sensitivity. study period We collected data for the period from December 7, 2009 to December 12, 2010. of all notified influenza cases in Berlin, 95% were reported before week 2 in 2010, which coincided with a decline of the german-wide consultation index of respiratory infections to background levels. the Vivantes hospital administration contributed weekly data on the aggregated numbers of all patients admitted to the hospital network. the study population was confined to patients aged 18 to 65 years.
